comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: The Marriage of Columbine Punch and Judy Theatre Opening:Nov 10, 1914 Closing: Dec 1914 Total Performances: 31 www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=8090

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: CUTEST OF ALL PLAYHOUSES TO OPEN TUESDAY NIGHT; Everything in Readiness for the First Performance of "The Marriage of Columbine" at the Punch and Judy Theatre. WITH six new shows opening in as many of the larger theatres last week it is strange that the coming week is to be given over entirely to the opening of the smallest theatre in the city, but on Tuesday night the new Punch and Judy Theatre, on Forty-ninth Street, near Broadway, will throw open its doors, when "The Marriage of Columbine," a new comedy in four acts, by Harold Chapin, will be the attraction. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60C16FE3B5916738... Mr. Charles Hopkins is the owner of the Punch & Judy, and Mrs. Hopkins does not appear to have a first name...

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: She's beautiful, with or without a name!!  :)

comment.author: 10799299@N00
comment._content: Her maiden name was Violet Vivian. She was from England, retired from the stage in 1919 and died in 1960. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30713FB3D541A7A... According to her obituary she was best know for playing Juliet in "Romeo and Juliet", Jim Hawkins in her husband's production of "Treasure Island" and Peter Pan in Barrie's Peter Pan.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: An article from 1911 that pokes light fun at Violet Vivian for her insistence on being known professionally as Mrs. Charles Hopkins: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1911-06-18/ed-... (lower right hand corner of newspaper page) history of the Punch and Judy Theatre, from "Demolished Broadway Theatres: www.musicals101.com/bwaypast5.htm "Punch and Judy 153 West 49th Street Later named: Charles Hopkins, Westminster, World, Embassy 49th Street Built: 1914 Demolished: 1987 Seats: 299 History: Actor Charles Hopkins built this as a home for experimental productions, and renamed it for himself in 1926. From 1933 on, this became a movie theatre under various names. Rockefeller Center purchased and demolished this structure to make way for another skyscraper."
